job_title: Medical Staff Services in Bakersfield, CA
pros: Family atmosphere and great people. Management listens and is always trying to improve. Employees truly care about patients and treat them like family.
cons: Don't let the small size of the hospital fool you. Even though it's 47 licensed beds, it's held to the same standard as a 500 bed hospital and employees are expected to wear multiple hats. If you are looking to gain a variety of skill sets, BHH is the place for you!

review_title: Was Excellent place for New Grads
pros: Small hospital, tight knit coworkers, lots of experience to be learned. This is a great place to come in and get experience before moving to a larger hospital.
cons: Missed breaks, high turnover amongst management, No phlebotomist, outdated electronic charting system.

pros: Good benefits, good food, that’s about it.

pros:

pros:
Every morning when I arrive to work I see people smiling and saying Good morning! The atmosphere is very loving and caring.  

I also enjoy coming to work.  The people I work with are a lot of fun and have a passion for what they do. It makes the workplace less stressful when you enjoy what you do. There are times when I notice a family in pain after the loss of a loved one or just the uncertainty of what is going on, so I make it a point to let them know there is complimentary coffee available in the cafe and I am willing to get it for them.   Taking the time to help others is what this hospital does!
cons: What I wish we had here is more beds so people wouldn't have to wait so long for treatment.

pros: I have never worked for an organization such as Bakersfield Heart Hospital. I witnessed so many heart-warming incidents over the past 6 months of my employment at BHH and observed our staff's reaction to a real life dangerous situation this past week. Although I was not in direct contact or directly exposed to this isolated critical situation, I gained such reassurance that Bakersfield Heart Hospital puts others hearts above their own. I have the honor of working at an organization where staff put patients, patients families and visitors above their own safety.
cons: I honestly do not have a con to leave at this time

pros: Great family feel for the most part. Most supervisors in most departments very helpful and encouraging. Loved feeling like this was going to be a long term career home.
cons: Upper management is only looking to fulfill their bottom line and don't care to lose long term loyal employees to new owners and their people. Willing to underpay some to force to leave and under staff to patient ratio and pay nurses to try to make them stay butet other departments suffer with work overload, under pay, under staff and even violate meal break and break rules. ER staff is definitely victims of this. Staff is overheard constantly about patients issues and staff is picked on by upper management. Old outdated equipment, low pay and the drive to pull "the boat around" by selling to whoever is willing to buy the hospital they are willing to throw their employees under the bus because they're so desperate to keep from going under. They ran off several great doctors due to their backward mentality of appeasing their new partners and get loans to get new equipment to make doctors want to do surgery there and bring their business there but departments would suffer for it. It was conveyed that the staff would be taken care but the patient was always first but the real feel was that money was being wasted and spent frivously to appear up to date. It's a smoke screen. Sad because they do great things there for the most part, but drop the ball for having their employees stay. Long term employees have left due to the poor management and bad politics of it all.
